name: Shadow Sculpting
description: Manipulate Darkness- Shape or thicken to Hide self or object; animate shadows (Death 2) or create out of nothing (Death 3).

name: Ectoplasmic Shaping
description: Sculpt Ectoplasm (Manifested Twilight matter) into desired form. Successes as Potency to usurp control from mage/ghost currently controlling it
rotePool: Presence + Occult + Death vs. Resolve + Gnosis (mage) or Resistance (ghost)

name: Grim Sight
description: Mage Sight: See Ghosts and Objects in Twilight. Spirits are not visible to Grim Sight. Successes to detect hiding apparition

name: Instill Mortality
description:
Reliquish a Spell without Willpower by Instilling Morality in the Enchanted Object. (starts @0)

When user fails on roll with Object, add 1 Mortality

Roll Mortality when used; Success=Structure Damage. Structure se the item malfunctions. None of its powers or enhancements can be used until it is repaired. If all Structure points are lost to damage, the item is destroyed.

On an exceptional success, the object is destroyed.

name: Pain Harvest
description:
After unwillingly undergoing an injury, the mage may intensify its severity, gaining a quantity of magical power that may be later used to relinquish control over a finishing spell.

This spell may only be cast after the mage has suffered at least one point of bashing, lethal or aggravated damage. The spell works only in the turbulent emotional aftermath of a genuine accident or attack by hostile others. The appropriate mental state can never be provoked by incidents of self-harm, or harm inflicted by one’s confederates. However, a qualifying incident may be engineered by provoking one’s enemies.

The spell is performed after the conclusion of the violent incident, before the mage seeks medical attention, pain relief or other healing. During the spell’s casting, the willworker uses a knife or similar implement to self-inflict up to three additional points of lethal damage. For each point suffered in this manner, the mage adds one to a pool of points known as a Pain Harvest pool. Only the self-inflicted damage contributes to the Pain Harvest pool.

The mage may at any subsequent time relinquish control over an imbued spell, curse, enhancement or defense installed in an Enchanted Item, by paying 12 points from her Pain Harvest pool.

name: Forensic Gaze
description:
The mage peers at a corpse to ascertain the cause of death -1 after 1 year dead, -1 for every decade after.

Can detect vampire and read source of death (-3 penalty)

name: Speak with the Dead
description:
The mage can see, hear and speak with ghosts within Twilight.

He can also detect their unseen presence, if they are hiding or have chosen not to reveal themselves. He can see spirits within Twilight, too, but they appear hazy and indistinct and he cannot hear them, unless he also uses Spirit ● while casting this spell. He cannot perceive mental projections unless he adds Mind ● to the casting.

name: Soul Marks
description:
This sense enables a mage to perceive a soul’s health.

He can discern the presence of derangements, but not necessarily their kind (that might require a period of study with an extended Intelligence + Empathy roll).

Other kinds of soul marks can also be detected, such as the telltale signs of a mage who has created a soul stone (see “Soul Stones,” p. 277). Some soul marks (such as serving as a vampiric vessel) are sufficiently rare and insidious as to penalize rolls made to perceive them.

name: Counterspell (Death)
description:
• The mage creates Pattern interference to weaken or cancel a Death spell.
  • Mage Sight is required to perceive the attacking spell and counter it.
  • Counterspell can be cast against vulgar spells from mages with higher Initiative.
  • Counterspell can also be used to counter sympathetic spells cast directly at the mage.
  • Successes subtract from the target spell's Potency; if reduced to zero, the spell is canceled.
  • Covert spells require identification before countering, while vulgar spells can be countered immediately.
  • Countering a spell aimed at multiple targets affects all targets.
  • Countering requires at least one dot in an Arcanum used by the attacking spell.

name: Lighten Anchor
description:
Increase the range a ghost can travel.

The ghost adds the spell’s Potency to its Power for the purpose of determining the range the ghost can roam from its anchors.

name: Corpse Unmasking
description: This spell allows the mage to detect whether or not the spell Corpse Mask had been used on a subject without undoing the Mask.

name: Touch of the Grave
description:
Through the casting of this spell, the mage gains the power to physically interact with ghosts and ghostly things in Twilight state.

She could, for example, pull a ghostly hammer out of a Twilight room in order to pound a nail into a wall. She could take the spectral reflection of a key out of the lock in which it was broken, pull it through into materiality, and use it to open the material lock barring her from entering a room she wishes to access.

She can also touch ghosts and be touched (or attacked) in return by any nearby shade. Such beings tend to be, at best, cold and clammy and many have other disturbing and not entirely tactile sensations associated with physical contact. Some spectres have been known to long for physical contact with the living in ways most unhealthy or inappropriate.

The caster cannot damage ghosts, or affect non-dead spirits such as fetches or mental projections, she needs the Spirit and Mind Arcana, respectively, for those effects.

name: Soul Jar (Death)
description:
This spell creates a receptacle to imprison the soul of the departed.

Any receptacle that can be used to seal liquid can serve as a soul jar, whether it’s a wine bottle, a preserve jar or even Tupperware. Success on the spellcasting enchants the receptacle so that a soul placed within the jar cannot escape. The jar’s lid is usually held fast by a metal bar or is coated with wax. The soul is protected from attack by the object. If the jar is opened or broken, the soul can flee. See “Soul Handling”

name: Suppress Aura
description:
The mage suppresses his own or another’s personal aura.

Effectively, he causes the aura to lapse into slumber, smoothing the telltale ripples it creates in the Tapestry and rendering it more difficult (or virtually impossible) to detect.

Each success levies a –1 penalty on any attempts to scrutinize the target’s aura.

name: Decay
description:
The mage can cause a material object to corrode, rust or become rotten.

This spell lowers the object’s Durability by one point per success, but it does not affect the object’s Structure (for that effect, see Destroy Object). The degraded Durability cannot be repaired by normal (non-magical) means.

name: Ghost Summons
description:
The mage calls a specific ghost or sends out a general call to the nearest ghost within sensory range.

He may either call one or more ghosts personally known to him, or he may specify any type of ghost of his choosing (male ghosts or child ghosts, for example), or even send out a general summons to all restless shades within his sensory range (in which case, the closest one to him responds). The ghost comes to the caster with as much speed as it can muster, although it cannot be made to go farther than the maximum distance it is allowed to travel from its anchor.

In the case of a general summons among multiple ghosts, the spell targets the closest one. A curious ghost will usually answer a general call or personal summons, but a reflexive, contested Resistance roll is made if it does not wish to come. It must remain near the summoning mage for the Duration of the spell, unless the caster allows it to leave.

name: Grant the Grim Sight
description:
The mage can give another supernatural being Mage Sight.

This is as the Death 1 Grim Sight spell, except that the mage casts it upon another mage or even a supernatural being such as a ghost or werewolf. If this spell is cast upon a Sleeper, it invokes Disbelief immediately, even if its Duration is less than one scene.

If the target is unwilling, a reflexive, contested Resolve + Gnosis roll is made.

name: Entropic Guard
description:
By stealing vigor from incoming attacks, a mage guards himself against harm.

Effectively, the mage’s shield attacks the vitality of an incoming assault, eroding its forcefulness with a primal decay.

The mage gains one point of armor per dot he possesses in the Death Arcanum. By spending one Mana, the Duration can be made one day. Most mages cast such a shielding spell at the beginning of the day, as part of their morning rituals. Successes are used to combat attempts to dispel the ward. Note that this magical armor does not apply against an opponent’s attempts to achieve a grappling hold on the mage (Fate, Mind, Space and Time Arcana provide shielding spells to accomplish that). This spell will, however, work to steal vigor from a grappler’s Strength + Brawl rolls to overpower the mage.

name: Animate Shadows
description:
As with Shadow Sculpting, but the mage can now cause the darkness to move, even causing it to travel from its naturally occurring place to somewhere darkness could not possibly exist, such as beneath the direct glare of a lamp.

The Speed at which the darkness can flow (directed by the caster as a reflexive action) is equal to the caster’s Gnosis + Death + the spell’s Potency.

name: Corpse Mask
description:
The mage alters the appearance of a death by adding or subtracting features from a corpse.

The mage could, for example, make the small pile of ashes left behind by a person killed by fire look as though she died from a stab wound to the neck. In this fashion, mages have turned murder most foul into seeming accidents or the product of natural causes, or taken a perfectly innocent circumstance (quiet heart failure in the night or a tumble down a flight of stairs) and used it to frame someone for a killing she never committed.

The mage can add or subtract one feature per success. A feature represents a single wound or disease condition, such as a laceration caused by a knife, burns caused by exposure to a conflagration, or a cancerous tumor in the target’s liver.

name: Bestow Ghostly Sight
description:
By altering the Pattern of a Sleeper’s perceptual capabilities, this spell enables the Sleeper to gaze into Twilight and perceive the shades of the dead.

Although covert in Aspect, this spell will invoke Disbelief if the Sleeper is in any way resistant to, or becomes especially terrified by, what he perceives (and most will be either one or the other, given the horror inherent in beholding the unquiet dead).

name: Final Sight
description:
This spell evokes ectoplasm from the eyes of a corpse, forming an ectoplasmic image of the last thing the corpse saw.

The effect is visible for all present to see, including Sleepers.

The spell requires the presence of a corpse. While the eyes do not need to be intact, the spell does require a more substantial corpse than mere ashes, though a decapitated head will suffice.

name: Ectoplasm
description:
The mage can create ectoplasm from one of his orifices (usually his mouth or nostrils) or the orifice of a corpse.

This opaque, white, slick material can be molded to form whatever shape the mage desires, although it cannot be disguised to look like some other substance (unless the mage adds Matter ●● to the casting). The mage could use it as a mirror to allow anyone (even Sleepers) to see ghosts or objects that are present in Twilight. Most often, it is used to allow a Twilight ghost to manifest without suffering any dice modifiers for location or the presence of mortals. The ectoplasm takes the shape of the ghost’s own image.

Successes are allocated between the ectoplasm’s Size and its solidity.

name: Curse of Withering
description:
The magician weaves a curse into a physical object, so that it gradually drains the life force from its owner.

To trigger the curse, a victim must take willing possession of the item. From that point onwards, the victim loses one dot in a Physical Attribute every time a predetermined interval passes. The shorter the interval, the greater the target number needed for casting:

  • 1 month = 5
  • 1 week = 10
  • 3days = 15
  • 1 day = 20

Dots are lost from the victim’s highest Attribute first. When two or more Attributes have the same current value, the Storyteller randomly chooses between them. This Attribute damage is permanent until the item is destroyed or disenchanted, or is willingly acquired by a new owner.

name: Destroy Ephemera
description:
The mage mystically attacks an ephemeral object.

Successes in excess of the object’s Durability (most ephemeral items have Durability 1) inflict aggravated damage on its Structure. This spell does not affect animate ephemeral beings such as ghosts (or anything with a Corpus trait rather than a Structure trait).

name: Control Ghost
description:
The mage can force a ghost to perform an action. A single, simple command (“Attack!” “Flee!” “Stand there!”) can be issued per success.

Complex commands require multiple successes. For example, “Go to the Contessa’s mansion and steal the Borgia Diamond!” might require three successes. If the ghost has not completed the action by the time the Duration expires, it does not have to finish the job. It must, however, work to complete the command as soon as possible.
rotePool: Presence or Manipulation + Intimidation + Death vs. Resistance

name: Shadow-Forged
description:
a Disciple of Death and Matter can draw the shadows down and weave them into sturdy, useful shapes such as swords, knives or simple tools.

Shadows pool around the mage and congeal into the desired form visualized in the Imago. With a single success, the shadows may be shaped into any Size 3 or smaller simple object (no moving parts). Durability for the shaped object is equal to twice the number of successes gained on the casting roll.

name: Ghostly Object
description: The mage creates a ghostly item by turning a real material object into a Twilight object. To do so, he must destroy the real object, eliminating all its Structure points, and then cast this spell upon its remains. The subject then becomes a ghost of itself within Twilight, allowing the mage to manipulate it with Death 2 (see the Touch of the Grave).

name: Summon Shadows
description: As with Shadow Sculpting and Animate Shadows but the mage now creates darkness from nothing. In addition, he gives it a semi-substantial form so that it can touch things and even provide a weak barrier.

name: Entropic Shroud
description:
The mage can cast the “Entropic Guard” spell (p. 136) on others, protecting them with a field of entropic decay.

The target gains one point of armor per dot the caster possesses in the Death Arcanum. The caster can increase the Duration to one day with the expenditure of one point of Mana.

name: Suppress Own Life
description:
The mage can temporarily suppress his own life. While in this state, the mage is well and truly dead. The physical symptoms of death, other than decomposition, set in (the onset and passing of rigor mortis, the receding of the gums and the skin of the scalp and fingertips, the pooling of blood at the bottom of the body). The mind and spirit are absent.

The mage determines a trigger that will wake him from this state (such as being struck or having a dog bark within earshot). Otherwise, he is dead until such time as the spell’s Duration runs out. Once awake, his Social rolls are penalized by –1 for every four hours he was under the spell’s effects (up to a maximum of –5). A character who looks like a walking corpse likely causes terror and repugnance. Penalties are reduced by one per hour after waking, as the mage regains his natural complexion.

name: Restore Corpus (Death)
description:
The mage can heal a ghost’s Corpus. 

One Corpus point of damage is restored per success.

name: Martyr's Bequest
description:
Successfully casting this spell, which may be used only by a mage who is unconscious due to damage, killing him instantly and irrevocably. 

If the mage is a Disciple of Life, he may freely distribute his body’s remaining fortitude to anyone within the spell’s Area, out to a limit of a person’s current maximum Health, healing any injury, whether bashing, lethal or aggravated, on a one-for-one basis.

If the mage is a Disciple of Mind, he may distribute his remaining points of Willpower in a similar manner, out to an individual’s current maximum.

If he is a Disciple of Prime, the willworker may distribute his remaining Mana and/or Tass (which dissolves to become Mana) to any individual capable of using such, adding it directly to her current stores, up to the maximum allowed by her Gnosis. Any or all of these effects may be combined into a single casting by a suitably skilled mage.

The caster’s body disintegrates completely upon the successful completion of this spell and he may not subsequently be summoned up in any form, unless somehow previously and willingly metaphysically bound to such a fate

name: Corpse Flesh
description:
Many philosophies throughout time have espoused the notion that life is pain and death brings surcease. Some Awakened could not agree more. This spell deadens the body’s pain responses and terminates.

Upon successfully casting this spell, and for the remainder of the scene, the mage no longer suffers wound penalties, does not need to breathe and does not begin to bleed to death when all of his Health boxes are filled with lethal damage[1]. Likewise, he does not register as a living pattern to sensory magics (though Life Arcanum spells can still affect him and he doesn’t count as a walking corpse for the purposes of the Death Arcanum), and perhaps most spectacularly, he can reattach severed pieces of his body with Life Arcanum healing (at the appropriate level for the type of damage sustained in losing the limb, or whatever other part was removed), so long as it is done before this spell’s Duration expires.

name: Destroy Object
description: The mage mystically attacks a material object, causing it to decay instantly.
rotePool: Resolve or Composure + Crafts or Science + Death

name: Healing the Dead Mind
description:
This spells works similarly to the Mind 4 spell “Augment Other’s Mind,” except that this spell only functions on ghosts. The spell brings a ghost to a level of self-awareness at which it can remember how it died (if it was in a position to know; a person who died of poisoning might know that much, but not who poisoned it) and what has happened to it since its death. This spell in no way makes the ghost well-disposed toward the mage. In fact, many ghosts despise the person who showed them their deaths

The mage must touch the ghost to use this spell, which requires the mage to be in Twilight, the ghost to manifest (see p. 210 of the World of Darkness Rulebook), or the mage to cast “Touch of the Grave”. At Death 4, the mage can cast this spell at sensory range, and can use advanced prolongation Duration factors. Some ghosts are self-aware to begin with, and this spell confers no further bonus on such shades.

name: Dissipate Unreal Construct
description:
By casting this spell, a mage can dissolve a Prime Arcanum phantasm, or other object crafted out of “unreal” matter (such as one sculpted out of ephemera and then drawn through the Gauntlet or one perhaps made by unusual Numina or the magics of other supernatural creatures).

Successes accrued during the casting of this spell inflict levels of bashing damage on an “unreal” construct (as defi ned above) on a one-for-one basis, circumventing Durability. If the object’s Structure is exceeded, the object disintegrates instantly.

name: Sever the Sleeping Soul
description:
The mage severs a soul from a Sleeper. While the soul is separated from the body, the subject suffers all the normal afflictions of soullessness. See “Soul Loss,” Mage the Awakening Sourcebook p. 276

The mage must touch the target for the entirety of the spellcasting. If he loses contact, he loses all accumulated successes. (With Death 5, he can cast this spell at sensory range. The spell cannot be cast sympathetically.) 

The victim must be rendered incapable of moving or escaping for the full length of the spellcasting. Relying on a grappling hold for a conscious victim is unwise, since the victim gets a chance to throw off the hold each turn, while it might take hours to complete the extended casting.

The target number is equal to the subject’s Willpower. Only a limited number of rolls are allowed for the caster, however, before his attempt is deemed a success or failure. A number of rolls may be made equal to his Resolve + Composure. If the spell fails, it cannot be recast on the same target until at least one day (24 hours) has passed.

With Death 5, the mage can sever an Awakened soul.

name: Sculpt Ephemera
description:
Inanimate objects and places within Twlight or the Shadow Realm are made from a substance called ephemera. The mage can shore up or degrade the Durability of such ephemera, and the item can be reshaped, changing a heap of metal into a bicycle frame or a stick into a spear. The mage cannot affect animate ephemera, such as a nature spirit or a fetch. Doing that requires Spirit.

Only one success is needed to reshape an object (if the new shape is very complex, the Storyteller might levy dice penalties to the casting). Or, one point of Durability is added per success. In the case of weapons or armor, successes can also be assigned to a weapon’s equipment bonus or to armor’s protection.

name: Ghost Gate
description:
The mage creates a gateway that transforms anyone who steps through it into a Twilight state of existence. They become Twilight beings until they exit the gateway. While Twilight, they can touch ghosts, pick up ghostly objects or read tomes hidden there. They can also engage in physical or magical combat with ghosts, damaging their Corpus. Conversely, wrathful shades might physically lash out at visitors, causing them harm.

One person of Size 5 or less can pass through the gate per turn (larger people can spend two turns squeezing through). Each success on the casting allows the mage to widen the gate so that one additional person can pass through per turn.

With Death ●●●●, the mage can cast this spell as an instant action and can also limit who can enter (or exit) the gate.

name: Devouring the Slain
description:
While any mage can commit a living sacrifice to gain Mana, this spell is an act of sorcerous cannibalism that allows a willworker to regain strength from the souls of the dying without necessarily killing them (although it certainly harms them).

The mage must first grab hold of the target, with a Strength + Brawl roll, subtracting the target’s Defense. If successful, he can cast this spell as an instant action in the following turn. (With Death ●●●●, he can cast this spell at sensory range as an instant action. He needs Death ●●●●● before he can add Space ●● for a sympathetic casting.)

Each success allows the mage to replenish one of his spent Willpower points by harvesting it from a person who has suffered at least one aggravated wound during the current scene (including one who has lost all of his Health to lethal damage and now suffers aggravated damage as his body dies), up to a maximum of the victim’s remaining Willpower points.

Alternatively, the mage may burn out a person’s Pattern for points of Mana, converting the ephemeral energies that make up his idealized form into raw power. Each success inflicts one lethal Health wound onto the victim and gives the caster one Mana point. If the victim is a mage, his own Mana points are unaffected; this spell steals energy directly from his Pattern. The caster must use the Prime ●●●●● Siphon Mana spell to directly tap an Awakened person’s Mana. Direct siphoning requires a separate casting from the Willpower-harvesting version of this spell, although both effects can be combined using the normal rules for combining spells (see “Combined Spells,”).

Devouring the Slain can be used only on a given individual once, after which a new level of aggravated damage must be inflicted upon him before he can again be a target.

name: Self Repairing Zombie
description: When cast upon a zombie, this spell enables the zombie to feed upon other dead flesh to mend its injuries and creates in it a compulsion to do so when reduced below a certain number of health boxes (determined by the caster). When reduced below this level and presented with any source of dead flesh, the zombie will feed, consuming one level of the corpse’s Size over the course of five turns and regaining one health box, until such time as the zombie is restored to at least the appropriate level of health programmed into the zombie by the caster. Note that the zombie can only be magically compelled to seek out alternate sources of sustenance by an effect that exceeds the Potency of this spell, though the zombie will break off from feeding to defend itself from harm.

name: Transfer Anchor
description: The mage severs a ghost’s relationship to its present anchor, designating a new one to take its place. The replacement anchor is often an Enchanted Item.

name: Arm Ghost
description: The mage casts Arm Ghost, then any other spell, with a ghost as the designated recipient of the second spell. That spell does not take effect; instead, the one-time ability to activate the spell’s effect passes to the ghost. The ghost can use the effect at any time thereafter, as an instant action. The roll for the subject spell is made when the ghost chooses to unleash it, using the mage’s relevant dice pool. The ghost gains the benefit from any positive effects of the roll that would apply to the mage. Where story logic permits, however, all ill effects, including Paradoxes and dramatic failures, are suffered by the willworker, even if she is a great distance from the ghost when the spell is used.

name: Quicken Corpse
description:
Quicken Corpse animates one or more corpses to serve as unfailing, devoted slaves. What such servants lack in wits and motivation, they more than make up for in dogged determination and sheer, tireless pursuit of the tasks they are set.

These corpse-slaves are not really any stronger than they were in life, but they are tireless and completely without the ability to sense or respond to pain. They need not eat or sleep and do whatever chore they are set to until told otherwise, even if it requires them to tear their own bodies apart in the attempt. They experience neither fear nor the desire for self-preservation and have no minds, per se, for others to control. They can, however, be wrested away from their master through the casting of this spell by another necromancer.

name: Slay Own Aura
description:
The mage destroys all sign of his own aura. This destruction permanently removes all signature of the mage’s current aura, such that it cannot be read by any magic.

The mage develops a new aura by the end of the week as his soul takes on new resonance based on his actions and character. This new aura cannot be recognized by anyone who has not examined it before, giving the mage a new mystical “fingerprint.” In the meantime, mages who use aura-perception spells to view the mage are unnerved by the target’s complete lack of an aura — an unnatural occurrence.

name: Soul Binding
description: The mage can attach a stolen soul to himself or another, but only if he or the target currently has no soul.

name: Enervation
description:
The mage can draw the vigor of life from a person’s body, leaving him weak and helpless, so that a weight-lifting champion is rendered barely able to lift a child’s toy.

The mage must first grab hold of the target, with a roll of Strength or Dexterity + Brawl – the target’s Defense. If successful, he can cast this spell as an instant action in the following turn. (With Death 5, he can cast this spell at Sensory Range as an instant action. He needs Death 6 before he can add Space 2 for a sympathetic casting.)

Each success subtracts one dot from the target’s Strength Attribute, down to a minimum of 1. The maximum amount by which Strength can be lowered is equal to the mage’s dots in the Death Arcanum. (Lowering Strength also lowers the target’s Speed trait.)

name: Revenant
description:
The mage prevents a recently dead Sleeper’s spiritual release. The casting of this spell must begin within an hour of the target’s death. This spell creates what some mages call a revenant, forcing the soul to inhabit a body that does not decompose for the duration of the spell.

The caster inculcates the revenant with one or more driving Passions related to achieving a certain goal — revenge, salvation — that strengthen it for its trials.

Only one success is required to animate a corpse and instill it with a Passion. Additional successes are added to the target number to boost the revenant’s traits, at a rate of one success per additional dot of any trait.

Although the target is dead, the Resolve Attribute it had in life is used to contest the magic.

With Death 5, the caster can make a recently dead mage into a revenant, although the revenant can no longer cast magic. (It contests with Resolve + Gnosis.)

name: Twilight Shift
description:
The mage can personally transform himself into the Twilight state of existence without needing to pass through a gateway.

All the mage’s clothing and equipment is likewise transferred into an ephemeral state, as long he touches it during casting. The mage can restore himself to a material state at anytime by dismissing the spell.

name: Haunting
description:
The mage causes a recently dead (within the past hour) or dying Sleeper to cling to a physical anchor rather than move on to whatever afterlife awaits. (The dying Sleeper begins haunting immediately upon physical death, so long as he dies within the Duration of the spell).

A point of Mana must be spent for the mage (above and beyond any other expenditures) to create an anchor for the ghost, which in this case need not be something precious to the subject. Excess successes can increase Duration.

With Death ●●●●●, a mage can create a haunting with a recently dead or dying mage or with a ghost who has been long dead.
rotePool: Presence or Intelligence + Persuasion + Death vs. Resolve (sleeper) or Resistance (ghost)

name: Suppress Other's Life
description:
The mage can suppress life in others temporarily. The effects are the same as the “Suppress Own Life” spell.

The mage must first grab hold of the target, with a Strength or Dexterity + Brawl – the target’s Defense. If successful, he can cast this spell reflexively. (With Death ●●●●●, he can cast this spell at sensory range. He needs Death ●●●●●● before he can add Space ●● for a sympathetic casting.)

If the target is attacked or harmed in any way during the time in which he appears to be dead, the spell is immediately broken and the target awakens. While “dead,” the target experiences nothing, as if he were merely in a deep sleep.
rotePool: Manipulation + Subterfuge + Death vs. Composure + Gnosis

name: Scourge Ghost
description:
The mage subjects a ghost to nearly unbearable psychic agony. Fear of this ghastly punishment inspires obedience in even the most willful phantom.

With the possible exception of utterly vile, deserving victims, the use of Scourge Ghost is an act of hubris, calling for a Wisdom degeneration roll, just as if the willworker had subjected a living victim to a session of appalling physical mistreatment.

name: Rotting Flesh
description:
Rotting Flesh rends and destroys the physical form of a living being, riddling it with corruption and putrefaction.

The mage must first grab hold of the target, with a roll of Strength or Dexterity + Brawl – the target’s Defense. If successful, he can cast this spell as an instant action in the following turn.(With Death 5, he can cast this spell at sensory range as an instant action. He needs Death 6 before he can add Space 2 for a sympathetic casting.)

Each success inflicts one Health point of lethal damage to the target and levies a -1 penalty on all of the victims Social Rolls due to the horrible appearance and stench of their wounds. With Death 5, the mage can inflict aggravated damage instead with the expenditure of one Mana.

name: Cloak of Decay
description:
As Destroy Object, except the mage surrounds himself with a field of entropy that acts to continually weaken melee weapons used to assault him. Each attack, successful or not, wears at weapons until attackers find their swords shattered, their knives dulled and their spears broken.

Each time the mage is attacked with a melee weapon (including improvised melee weapons), roll dice of damage equal to spell Potency against that weapon. Even entering the area created by Cloak of Decay can cause damage to weaponry. A damage roll is made against an attacker’s weapon even if the attack misses. This spell has no effect on ranged weapons or on any type of bare-fisted Brawling attack.

name: Quell the Spark
description:
The mage can dispel any spell, regardless of what Arcana were used to create it — he does not need Prime ● or any other Arcana lore. The mage must first have Mage Sight so that he can perceive the spell to be affected.

Successes are compared to the target spell’s Potency. If they equal or exceed it, the spell is dispelled.

name: Devouring the Living
description:
The mage consumes a healthy lifeforce or ghost. 

This spell is handled in exactly the same way as Devouring the Slain, save that the mage may now perform the spell upon a healthy subject (one not currently suffering from aggravated damage) or a nearby ghost (damaging the spirit’s Corpus). The mage must still grab hold of the target first. (unless he has Death ●●●●●●, allowing him to cast the spell within sensory range as an instant action).
rotePool: Manipulation+ Intimidation + Death - Stamina (living) or Resistance (ghost)

name: Create Ghost
description:
This spell reaches back into the past, to the moment of an individual’s death, and calls his ghost into the present day. This spell calls forth the dead person’s ghost, exactly as it would have been if the person’s death had created a ghost. In addition, this ghost appears exactly as it would have within a few hours or days after the person’s death.

To use this spell, the mage must have a sympathetic connection to either the person’s place of death or to his body. Mages who cast this spell at the place of death, with a piece of the deceased’s body on hand, receive a +2 bonus to this spell.

name: Summon the Dead
description:
The mage can summon a ghost from the Underworld, making it appear next to him within Twilight. The caster can use other spells to compel the ghost to manifest, or can provide ectoplasm for its manifestation. This spell is most often cast to learn the secrets of the long-departed, such as the locations of lost treasures or the existence of lost heirs.

The mage can ask one question of the ghost per success. After it has answered it departs, returning to the Underworld. (The mage cannot delay for more than five turns between questions, or else the ghost departs.) The entity’s answers are truthful and straightforward, although if a question is not clear and concise, the ghost might misinterpret it and give a misleading answer.
rotePool: Presence or Manipulation + Persuasion + Death vs. Resistance

name: Destroy Mana
description:
The mage can destroy Mana. 

One point of Mana, no matter how it is stored (as tass, within an artifact, or a mage’s own personal Mana points), may be destroyed per success.

name: Steal Lifespan
description:
The mage steals years of life from a Sleeper to extend his own life. This spell cannot be cast upon supernatural beings, including the Awakened.

The target number of successes equals the number of years sought from the target, although the mage may not steal more years with a single casting than his total dots in Death. The mage can cast this spell on the same target only once a year.

This effect is largely in the hands of the Storyteller. It is a means mages can use to live beyond a normal mortal life span, although it does not prevent the effects of aging nor death by calamity.

name: Secret Marriage (Death)
description:
The mage installs a willing ghost in a protohomunculus, giving the subject a lasting body in the Material Realm.

The spell may not be used on a proto that has already had Construct Homunculus Persona cast on it. The Traits of the new homunculus are figured as follows. Its Physical Attributes and Skills are as determined by Construct Homunculus Form. The homunculus gains Intelligence and Presence dots equal to the ghost's Power dots, Wits and Manipulation equal to its Finesse dots and Resolve and Composure equal to its Resistance dots. The homunculus gains whatever Mental and Social Skills the Storyteller feels are appropriate for the type of spirit or ghost (if any), along with any Flaws and/or derangements. Any supernatural powers arising from their status as discarnate entities are unavailable to them while in homunculus form.

While some ghosts crave the ability to operate in the Material Realm conveyed by possession of a homunculus form, they generally feel this way because they want to pursue a specific agenda of some kind. Savvy mages should expect the average ghost to display only minimal loyalty and cooperation, except where their own interests converge with those of the discarnate entities they’ve gifted with physical forms.

The most loyal homunculi created in this manner are generally the ghosts of slain cabal members, who use their flawed new forms to further the collective goals they fought for while alive.

name: Quicken Ghost
description:
The mage quickens a ghost, restoring mindless shades to a semblance of the personality they had in life, and turning ancient ghosts into more potent specters.

Each success raises one of a ghost’s three Attributes by one or provides it with one Essence (this bonus cannot cause a ghost to possess more Essence than it can normally hold).

name: Sharpshooter's Eye
description:
• This spell enhances ranged attacks by eliminating minor random factors and providing a flawless lock on the target.
  • Using Life 1 or Matter 1, the mage gains a lock on a living creature or an object, respectively.
  • Each success reduces one die of ranged combat penalties due to target distance, position, size, or environmental factors.
  • The spell applies to the next roll the caster makes against the locked target.
  • If the target leaves the caster's direct sight, the lock is lost and the spell must be cast again.
  • Cannot be cast in combination with the Space 1 Spatial Map spell.

name: The Sybil's Sight
description:
• The mage gains Mage Sight, allowing them to detect the qualities of mystic forces in their interactions with fate.
  • Successes in the scrutiny reveal clues about various aspects of the investigated resonance.
  • The Storyteller should make the rolls, sharing information each time a success is rolled.
  • The analysis can yield useful information even if the scrutiny is abandoned before completion.
  • Suggested equipment, such as crystals or gems, can enhance the appearance of resonance.
  • The density of the subject affects the dice pool with corresponding modifiers.
  • The mage can detect momentous events by making a reflexive Wits + Investigation roll.
  • This ability allows the mage to sense when someone speaks or something significant happens in a metaphysical sense.
  • The ability is not intended for fishing for prophecies and has limitations in interpreting the meaning of detected events.

name: Quantum Flux
description:
• This spell allows the mage to read probabilities and compensate for small deleterious factors.
  • The mage can spend time "aiming" an action, reducing dice-pool penalties on a one-for-one basis.
  • The maximum reduction is three dice worth of penalties.
  • The effect only negates penalties and does not provide a bonus to dice pools.
  • The mage can mitigate factors such as weather conditions or other minor obstacles.

name: Synchronicity
description:
• Synchronicity allows the mage to gain cryptic guidance from apparent coincidences or random inputs.
  • The mage opens herself up to random input, such as flipping through TV channels or letting an encyclopedia fall open to a random page.
  • The random input provides an oblique hint or opportunity to act, suggesting a course of action or answer to a question.
  • A Potency of 3 or higher provides clearer answers, while an exceptional success suggests an obvious course of action.
  • Synchronicity requires the player to interpret the random input with creativity.

name: Winds of Chance
description:
• The mage has the ability to influence luck and attract good or ill fortune.
  • This effect is more of a roleplaying consideration and can be used to create interesting or chaotic situations.
  • The mage can enhance their own luck or manipulate the luck of others.
  • The outcome of these manipulations can result in fortunate or unfortunate events.
  • This power can be used to create comedic or dramatic moments in the narrative.

name: Reading the Outermost Eddies
description:
• This spell allows the mage to manipulate small twists of fate or gain insights into immediate random actions.
  • The mage can use this spell to know the outcome of small random events in their immediate vicinity.
  • The spell can bring about small turns of good fortune or provide insights for favorable outcomes.
  • It cannot be used to change the probability of events already set in motion or to bring about life-altering changes.
  • Repeated attempts to use the spell for the same goal are considered vulgar and may result in ill luck.

name: Sacrifice Fortune
description:
• This spell allows the mage to forgo an exceptional success and gain a point in the Sacrifice Fortune pool.
  • The exceptional success is downgraded to a standard simple success.
  • The Sacrifice Fortune pool can be used to relinquish control over a finishing spell by paying seven points.
  • Exceptional successes at events of little relevance or actions with no additional benefit do not qualify for this spell.
  • The Sacrifice Fortune pool can be accumulated over time for future use.

name: Interconnections
description:
• This spell reveals interconnections and themes between people, places, and things.
  • The mage can sense the degree of sympathetic connection between subjects and detect manipulations of destiny.
  • Success allows the mage to examine anyone in sensory range and determine their interconnections.
  • Each success on an extended roll provides information about the connections, with more successes revealing more powerful or secret connections.
  • The mage can identify different levels of connections and also detect supernatural mind control, spiritual possession, and alterations of destiny.

name: Counterspell (Fate)
description:
• The mage creates Pattern interference to weaken or cancel a Fate spell.
  • Mage Sight is required to perceive the attacking spell and counter it.
  • Counterspell can be cast against vulgar spells from mages with higher Initiative.
  • Counterspell can also be used to counter sympathetic spells cast directly at the mage.
  • Successes subtract from the target spell's Potency; if reduced to zero, the spell is canceled.
  • Covert spells require identification before countering, while vulgar spells can be countered immediately.
  • Countering a spell aimed at multiple targets affects all targets.
  • Countering requires at least one dot in an Arcanum used by the attacking spell.

name: Shifting the Odds
description:
• The mage creates small shifts of destiny, generating turns of good or bad luck.
  • The shifts are plausible situations that manipulate fortune in a desired direction.
  • The mage requests a small jolt in the desired outcome, leaving the specifics up to destiny.
  • The outcomes may come about in unexpected ways, requiring the mage to be alert and adaptable.
  • These manipulations can lead to bigger and more meaningful outcomes if nurtured and pursued.

name: Heroic Effort
description:
• The mage casts this spell to enhance her chances of success in a desperate situation.
  • The spell lasts for a limited duration and affects the next chance roll the mage makes.
  • During the affected roll, the mage treats her dice pool as one, with a chance to succeed on eight through 10.
  • The mage cannot dramatically fail the roll in question.
  • Once the chance roll is modified, the spell automatically expires.

name: Dialing the Lucky Number
description:
• The mage uses this spell to make a phone ring, specifically the phone nearest to the person they want to contact.
  • If the target's phone remembers dialed numbers, it can be a way to discover their cell phone number.
  • The target is not compelled to answer the phone, and there is no guarantee that they will be the closest person to the phone.
  • The spell manipulates the phone system, not the remote person, so it is not sympathetic magic.
  • Each use of the spell allows for one phone call, and repeated use does not become Improbable Magic.

name: Reveal Enigmas
description:
• This spell uncovers patterns and enhances the mage's mind to solve complex puzzles and secrets hidden within them.
  • The mage can use this spell to provide answers to puzzles that can be solved with an instant action.
  • If the puzzle is physical, such as a jigsaw puzzle or combination lock, Matter • is also required.
  • A single success is enough for simple puzzles like reassembling a jigsaw puzzle or knowing the answer to a riddle.
  • Multiple successes are often needed for more complex mechanical puzzles or decoding codes.

name: Fate's Justice
description:
• This spell invokes Fate to curse the subject before they take a particular action, typically a hostile action against the caster.
  • Success subtracts dice equal to the caster's Fate dots from the subject's dice pool for the next action.
  • Each additional success affects an additional dice roll.
  • The curse takes effect immediately before the action and die roll that triggers it.

name: Exceptional Luck
description:
• The mage gains the 9-again quality, allowing them to re-roll results of 9 and 10, on one future dice roll per success.
  • The player can choose which roll is affected by the exceptional luck, declared before rolling the dice.
  • This effect lasts for one scene, unless additional Duration factors are added during casting.
  • Unused luck rolls are lost after the scene ends.
  • This spell does not affect chance dice, and only a result of 10 is considered a success.

name: Sniffing the Winds of Fate
description:
• This spell provides the caster with a sense of the subject's ultimate destiny and how close they are to that fate.
  • The subject's ultimate outcome is revealed through a golden aura or a gray shroud, indicating the magnitude of their impact on the world.
  • It can be used on living creatures and inanimate objects to determine their fate and the effects of entropy.
  • The default fate of the subject is revealed, but with extraordinary action, this fate can be altered.
  • The spell can sense if the subject possesses the Destiny Merit and gauge its strength.
  • An exceptional success allows the mage to learn more specific information, including the cause and immediate circumstances of the subject's death.
  • If the subject's destiny has been magically occluded, the spell's Potency must exceed the occluding magic.

name: Fortunate Timing
description:
• This spell allows the mage to experience fortunate circumstances involving timing.
  • The mage will be in the right place at the right time to meet someone, get a ride, or assist/prevent events.
  • The spell requires surrendering to the moment and allowing Fate to guide the caster.
  • The circumstances created by the spell will not be inherently dangerous or detrimental.
  • Repeated casting of the spell can tangle the threads of Fate and disrupt the intended circumstances.
  • The spell is more story-related than mechanical, allowing the Storyteller to arrange the plot in an expedient manner.

name: The Evil Eye
description:
• This spell is a basic curse intended to bring about immediate ill-fortune upon another.
  • The caster directs a baleful glare or uses less obvious means to hex the target's actions.
  • Success subtracts a number of dice from the target's dice pool for the next action they take.
  • One die is subtracted per Fate dot the caster possesses.
  • Extra successes on the spell casting affect additional rolls made by the target.
  • Some mages prefer to use a conditional trigger to delay the onset of the curse until specific conditions are met.
  • The Fate Break the Chains spell can dispel the Evil Eye.
rotePool: Manipulation or Wits + Persuasion + Fate - Composure

name: Platonic Mechanism
description:
• This spell imbues a mechanical item with perfect precision and flawless functioning.
  • The enchanted device functions flawlessly for as long as it is meant to function.
  • The device performs at 100% physical efficiency, becoming a physical representation of the Platonic Ideal of such machines.
  • The device is not more resilient to damage, but it is protected from normal environmental hazards based on its intended use.
  • Dramatic failures associated with the "perfected" device are ignored.
  • The device always works as it was designed, ensuring flawless performance in "normal" use.
  • The risk of Disbelief is minimal as most people cannot distinguish a "perfect" item from an ordinary one.

name: Querulous Minds
description:
• This spell allows the mage to detect Sleepers who have had an experience with the supernatural.
  • The mage can scan the auras of those around them to look for any hint of a supernatural encounter.
  • A person who has had a supernatural encounter will have a more conspicuous aura, which may appear as silver threads, emit a specific odor, or be sensed intuitively by the mage.
  • If the number of successes on the roll is equal to or less than the Potency of a relevant effect hiding the target, the mage sees only a normal aura.

name: Loyal Possession
description:
• This spell attunes an item to the mage, ensuring it returns to its rightful owner if separated without consent.
  • The spell works through a series of subtle turns of fate and slight of mind, guiding the item back to its owner through seemingly random events.
  • Sleepers can act as unwitting agents in returning the item, and seemingly "random" events conspire to facilitate its return.
  • The time it takes for the item to return depends on circumstances, ranging from hours to days.
  • There are limitations to the spell: it doesn't work if the item's owner willingly gives it away, it remains with an Awakened character if they keep it on their person, and it becomes stuck if brought inside a ward.
  • Valuable items and artifacts may have similar capabilities of loyal possession.

name: Swearing an Oath
description:
• This spell allows the mage to swear an oath, declaring their intentions officially to Creation.
  • The oath grants the opportunity for the mage to reflexively roll Resolve + Composure in circumstances that would normally forbid action, enabling them to act even when mentally compelled or controlled.
  • Upholding the oath may allow the mage to regain a spent Willpower point, similar to indulging their Vice.
  • The mage cannot cancel their own oath spell unless they possess Fate 4; they must dispel it if they no longer desire its effect.
  • Knowingly and willingly breaking the oath results in suffering the effects of the "Evil Eye" spell, and the penalty cannot be undone without Fate 4.
  • The mage can only swear one oath at a time, but they can have multiple geas cast upon them.

name: Fortune's Protection
description:
• The mage creates a web of probability that protects her from attacks, making them unlikely to affect her.
  • The mage gains one point of armor per dot in the Fate Arcanum.
  • By spending one Mana, the Duration of the spell can be extended to last for one day.
  • Successes on the casting roll are used to combat attempts to dispel the shield.
  • The magical armor provided by the spell applies against attempts to grapple the caster, reducing the attacker's dice pool by the mage's Defense and Fortune's Protection armor.
  • The armor does not protect against attempts to overpower or inflict damage once the mage has been grappled.

name: The Perfect Moment
description:
• This spell allows the caster to act with perfect grace and timing in social situations, saying the right things at the right moments.
  • The mage goes with the flow, letting Fate and instincts guide their actions.
  • The caster must not have foreknowledge of the circumstances to maintain the necessary randomness.
  • Repeated casting of the spell in relation to the same subject can entangle or sever threads of destiny.
  • The spell moves into the realm of manipulating the story rather than relying on dice rolls.
  • Favorable results of the spell typically do not last beyond its Duration.
  • Unfavorable side effects can occur, often reversing the fortune the spell provided.

name: Grant the Sybil's Sight
description:
• This spell is similar to the Fate ● Sybils Sight spell, but it can be cast on another mage or supernatural being.
  • If cast on a Sleeper, it immediately invokes Disbelief, regardless of its Duration.
  • If the target is unwilling, they can contest the spell with a reflexive Resolve + Gnosis roll.

name: Cursed Object
description:
• This spell imbues an item with bad luck, which affects its primary owner or user.
  • The Potency of the spell cannot exceed the caster's total Fate dots.
  • To weave the curse into the item, the caster must spend one Mana and achieve five successes on the spell's target number.
  • When the user touches or uses the cursed item, there is a possibility of ill luck. The Storyteller rolls a single die, and on a result of one, the curse activates.
  • If the curse activates, the victim suffers a penalty to their next die roll equal to the Potency of the curse.
  • The curse should be passed to another person as soon as possible to avoid its effects returning to the caster.
  • The Storyteller may determine specific activities that qualify as "use" of an item.

name: Lucky Coin
description:
• This spell allows the mage to interact with a lifeless object and enhance its performance.
  • By touching the object's destiny, the mage fortifies its ability to perform its intended tasks.
  • On the turn after casting, the targeted object receives an equipment dice bonus equal to the spell's successes, up to a maximum of the caster's Fate dots.
  • A suit of armor's protection can be increased by one point per success, up to a maximum of the caster's Fate dots.
  • Lucky objects tend to benefit their owners even without direct use (e.g., a lucky jacket saving the mage from a fall).
rotePool: Wits or Presence + Occult or Science + Fate

name: Occlude Destiny
description:
• This spell creates an "inviolable fate" by preventing outside powers from perceiving or tampering with a given destiny.
  • The mage can conceal a person favored or ill-favored by fate, protecting them from detection or alteration by those with the ability to perceive such things.
  • The spell's Potency contends against other mages' attempts to perceive or alter the target's destiny.
  • If cast upon an unwilling mage, a contested Composure + Gnosis roll is made to resist the spell.

name: Bestow Exceptional Luck
description:
• This spell allows the mage to grant others the 9-again quality for one or more rolls.
  • The 9-again quality allows for re-rolling results of 9 and 10 on the dice.
  • The mage can choose which rolls are affected by this enhanced luck.
  • The spell's effects last for the duration specified by the caster.

name: Monkey's Paw
description:
• This spell allows the mage to bring bad fortune onto lifeless objects.
  • The targeted object is subject to an equipment dice penalty equal to the spell's successes.
  • A suit of armor's protection can be decreased by one point per success.
  • The effects of this spell can cause harm or misfortune to the owner of the object.
  • Unlucky objects may bring ill fortune even without being used by their owner.

name: Bad Penny
description:
• This spell further enchants a cursed item, creating a chain of coincidences that ensure its return when anyone other than the original caster tries to dispose of it.
  • Examples include a smashed ceramic statue being repaired and returned or a thrown-out DVD being found by the owner's best friend and given as a gift.
  • The item will continue to reappear through coincidences until it makes a final reappearance, after which the owner can destroy or dispose of it.
  • For each additional spell or enchantment on the item, the caster must achieve five additional successes in the spellcasting.
  • If Disbelief is triggered by later manifestations, it can potentially dispel the curse if the Sleeper accumulates enough Resolve + Composure successes to exceed the Potency of the original spell.

name: Blessing
description:
• The mage shields a target from harm by manipulating lucky coincidences that help the target avoid specific dangers.
  • The required number of successes in the spell depends on the level of danger the mage wishes to protect against (e.g., embarrassment, inconvenience, injury, or death).
  • If successful, the target is protected from the specified danger for the spell's duration (one hour or one scene).
  • This spell does not work on other mages, and those with an active Blessing spell stand out to Fate.
  • The spell ends once the specified danger has been avoided, regardless of remaining Duration.
  • The protection provided is through coincidences and happenstance that remove the target from harm's way.
  • If the target seeks out the specified danger, the spell only protects them once.
  • If the target has a death wish or actively seeks trouble, they can contest the spell unconsciously with a Composure roll.

name: Fabricate Fortune
description:
• The mage creates a false destiny for a person or object, making it appear destined to a specific outcome.
  • This deception can mislead others who have the ability to perceive destiny or fortune.
  • Those attuned to prophecy must overcome the spell's Potency to see through the false destiny.
  • If the spell is cast on an unwilling mage, they can make a contested Composure + Gnosis roll to resist its effects.
rotePool: Intelligence + Subterfuge + Fate vs Composure + Gnosis

name: Alter Oath
description:
• The mage has the ability to alter the terms and conditions of a Fate-based oath.
  • Attempting to get someone to alter the terms of their oath may be seen as intent to violate the oath and subject the mage to the consequences of breaking an oath.
  • The Potency of the targeted oath acts as dice penalties to the casting roll of this spell.
  • Once an oath is altered, the changes remain in effect for the duration of the spell.
  • A mage cannot alter an oath they have made for themselves until they have reached Fate 4.
rotePool: Manipulation or Wits + Politics + Fate - Resolve

name: Instill Malediction
description:
• The mage can relinquish a finishing spell without sacrificing a Willpower point by making the Enchanted Item a focus for future ill-fortune.
  • A Misfortune pool is attached to the item, with each failure scored by the user adding a die to the pool.
  • Before using the item with a Misfortune greater than zero, the user must roll its Misfortune pool.
  • On a failure, the item remains sound and can be used as normal during the current turn.
  • On a success, the item can still be used but at a dice penalty equal to the number of Misfortune successes.
  • On an exceptional success, a random curse permanently instills itself in the item.
  • The Storyteller chooses an appropriate curse or rolls a die to determine the curse from a chart.

name: Superlative Luck
description:
• The mage is blessed with amazing luck that defies the odds and credibility.
  • For each success achieved in the spellcasting roll, the mage gains the 8-again quality, allowing them to reroll results of 8, 9, and 10, on one future dice roll.
  • The player can choose which roll is affected by this luck, and it can involve any action or task.
  • This effect lasts for one scene, unless additional Duration factors are added during casting.
  • Unused luck rolls are lost after the scene ends.
  • Note that this spell does not affect a chance die, and only a result of 10 is considered a success.

name: Tangle the Threads
description:
• The spell creates a defensive barrier around the caster, making it difficult for others to manipulate their destiny with the Fate Arcanum.
  • Each success assigned to the spell's Potency increases the number of successes required to manipulate the caster's destiny with Fate magic.
  • The caster's destiny is convoluted and filled with conflicting emotions and compulsions, making it challenging to navigate.
  • The spell defends against certain Fate-based effects that are "under the radar" of the Unfettered Fate 4 effect, such as Monkey's Paw and Alter Oaths.
  • Other Fate magics in the area still work normally, including those indirectly targeting the caster.

name: Grant Fortune's Protection
description: As with the Fate 2 “Fortune Protection” spell, but the mage can now cast this upon others.

name: Sever Oaths
description:
• The mage has the ability to completely sever an oath or manipulate an oath they have sworn.
  • The number of successes needed to sever an oath must exceed the Potency of the oath.
  • If the mage targets one of their own oaths, one success is enough to sever it.

name: Destroy Bindings
description:
• The mage can free a soul that has been forcibly bound outside of its proper place.
  • The spell can sever the connection between a mage and her familiar, release a spirit from a fetish, or free a ghost from an anchor.
  • The caster's successes must exceed the Potency of the bond or the Resistance dots of the ghost.
  • The release of a trapped soul and the release of a bound spirit or ghost are lasting.
  • A familiar bond returns to normal at the end of the scene, but the duration can be prolonged.
  • For freed souls, they must be restored to their rightful owner using the Spirit ●●● Restore Lost Soul spell.
rotePool: Resolve or Intelligence + Occult + Fate vs. bond Potency

name: Sanctify Oaths
description:
• The mage can witness others swearing oaths and bring the weight of destiny to bear upon them.
  • The target(s) do not need to be aware of the mage's ability to enhance their vows with metaphysical momentum.
  • If the target is unaware, they can unconsciously contest the spell with a Resolve + Gnosis roll.
  • This spell counts towards the total number of spells the mage can maintain, but the mage can choose to relinquish control of the spell.
rotePool: Presence + Expression + Fate vs. Resolve + Gnosis

name: Gift of Fortune
description:
• A mage can manipulate the destiny of objects and influence their paths of acquisition or movement.
  • The mage can attract objects to themselves or send them to specific individuals or locations.
  • The spell's success is determined by the metaphysical weight of the object's current destiny.
  • Moving highly significant objects may require more successes, while lesser-known objects may require fewer.
  • The targeted object's journey can be expedited by accruing excess successes.
  • A sympathetic connection through the Space Arcanum is needed to cast the spell, with the strength of the connection affecting the spellcasting roll.

name: Probable Cause
description:
• The mage enhances their probability of success in any endeavor they undertake.
  • For each success achieved in the casting roll, the mage gains the rote quality (reroll failed dice once) on one future dice roll.
  • The player can choose which rolls are affected by the altered probability.
  • This effect lasts for one scene, and any unused rote rerolls are lost after the scene ends.
  • The spell cannot be combined with Exceptional Luck or Superlative Luck spells, and only the most potent spell takes effect.

name: Coincidental Travel
description:
• The mage reshapes the threads of fate to facilitate her journey to a chosen destination.
  • Coincidences and favorable events occur to aid the mage along her way, such as discounted fares, free tickets, smooth traffic, and short lines.
  • A single success on the spell allows the mage to make an easy and low-cost journey to any destination in 10% below the minimum time normally required.
  • Additional successes further reduce the travel time by 10% each, up to a maximum reduction of 50%.
  • Sympathetic connection plays a role, and the mage may receive penalties based on the familiarity of the destination.
  • The spell cannot bypass security measures or allow access to restricted areas.

name: Forbidden Fate
description:
• The mage alters someone's destiny, making it extremely difficult for them to achieve a specific goal of their choosing.
  • The target experiences a string of unfortunate events and obstacles that hinder their attempts to accomplish the chosen goal.
  • The goal must be a deliberate choice by the target and not essential for survival.
  • Examples of valid goals include defeating an enemy, acquiring a specific object, applying for a job, giving a speech, running for office, or creating artwork.
  • Actions taken by the target to directly achieve the forbidden goal suffer a dice penalty equal to the caster's Fate Arcanum dots.

name: Forge Destiny
description:
• The mage has the power to determine the destiny of a living being.
  • Successes on the spellcasting roll can be used to add dice to actions that align with the declared fate or impose dice penalties on actions that go against it.
  • The Storyteller determines when penalties apply, usually when the target tries to resist or deny the imposed fate.
  • The effect lasts for one scene, but sufficient Duration can be assigned for longer-term fates.
  • When influencing an artificially created destiny, the caster must overcome the Potency of the original spell that imposed it.
rotePool: Manipulation or Intelligence + Persuasion + Fate vs. Resolve + Gnosis

name: Great Curse
description:
• This spell is a more powerful version of The Evil Eye.
  • It affects all rolls made by the victim while the spell is in effect.
  • This spell cannot be combined with The Evil Eye; only the most potent spell takes effect.

name: Swarm of Locusts
description:
• The mage can create chaotic conditions and bizarre phenomena.
  • The effects of the spell are surrendered to Fate's hands, and the mage has no control over them.
  • Sleepers who witness the chaos are temporarily open to the possibilities of magic and do not cause Paradoxes for any spell they witness in the affected area.
  • The size of the area affected by the chaos depends on the number of successes rolled.
  • The chaos may adversely affect the caster or their allies, resulting in potential dice penalties on certain rolls.
  • The spell cannot be cast again in the same area or adjacent areas for the next 24 hours.

name: Geas
description:
• The mage can create a geas, compelling another individual to heed their will.
  • The target must do as they are bidden or suffer the enmity of destiny.
  • The mage is not obligated to be reasonable with the commands, but they must be possible to achieve.
  • Violating the terms of the geas during its duration results in suffering the effects of the Great Curse.
  • The duration of the geas can be extended, with longer durations imposing dice penalties on the target.
rotePool: Presence + Expression + Fate vs. Resolve + Gnosis

name: Break the Chains
description:
• The mage has the ability to dispel or rearrange the conditions of another mage's Geas.
  • Successes must exceed the Potency of the Geas in order to effectively manipulate it.
rotePool: Wits or Resolve + Occult + Fate vs. geas Potency

name: Forge Doom
description:
• The mage has the ability to declare someone's doom, which can be a living being, place, thing, condition, flaw, or behavior.
  • When in direct confrontation with the declared doom or while acting within its parameters, any damage suffered by the subject is increased by the spell's successes.
  • The damage type does not change; it only amplifies the damage that would normally occur.
  • Meeting a doom does not guarantee immediate harm, but it worsens any damage that might occur within the parameters of the doom.
  • The default area affected by a place doom is a one-yard radius or five-cubic yards of volume.
rotePool: Resolve + Intimidation + Fate vs. Resolve + Gnosis

name: Infectious Curse
description:
• The mage spreads the effects of the Great Curse through contagion, creating an infectious plague of ill fortune.
  • The spell's effects not only affect the initial target but also anyone with whom they come in contact.
  • The spell cannot have an indefinite Duration to prevent the curse from growing uncontrollably.
  • The initial target cannot resist the curse, but subsequent potential targets can contest the spell's effect with a Composure + Gnosis roll.

name: Forge Godsend
description:
• The mage designates a living being, place, thing, condition, behavior, or physical strength as a godsend.
  • The successes achieved in the spellcasting roll determine the level of protection provided by the godsend.
  • When in possession of, acting under the parameters of, or within the presence of a godsend, the spell's successes are subtracted from any damage suffered by the mage.
  • The spell prioritizes subtracting successes from aggravated damage, then lethal damage, and finally bashing damage.
  • In the case of a place made into a godsend, the default area affected is a radius of one yard or a volume of five cubic yards.
rotePool: Composure + Survival + Fate vs. Resolve + Gnosis

name: Tune In
description:
This spell enables a mage to listen in on a free-floating data transmission (like that of a cellular modem) and translate the electromagnetic “noise” into intelligible information.

A Wits + Science roll is made for the mage to discern transmissions. Electromagnetism travels vast distances in a short period of time; signals are bounced all over the place by satellites (both natural and artificial), the Earth’s atmosphere and various other things. Encrypted signals levy a penalty on perception rolls equal to the successes initially accrued in encrypting the signal.

name: Receiver
description:
The mage can hear sounds on subsonic or supersonic frequencies that the human ear cannot normally distinguish, but this spell does not improve her hearing ability.

A Wits + Composure roll is made for the mage to discern high-frequency sounds (a dog whistle) or low-frequency sounds (the rumble of a distant herd of elephants). Sounds that are very high or low on the scale from the normal human range of hearing might impose dice penalties.

name: Influence Heat
description:
The mage can guide the direction and/or flow of existing heat.

He could, for example, keep warm in cold weather by pulling the ambient warmth shed by other human bodies to himself, or make sure that the dim heat from a radiator on the other side of a bathroom reached the shower stall. He could not increase the temperature of the heat at this level, nor create heat where there is none.

name: Read Matrices
description:
• The mage gains Mage Sight, allowing them to perceive energy and magical resonance.
  • Successes in the scrutiny reveal clues about various aspects of the investigated resonance.
  • The Storyteller should make the rolls, sharing information each time a success is rolled.
  • The analysis can yield useful information even if the scrutiny is abandoned before completion.
  • Suggested equipment, such as crystals or gems, can enhance the appearance of resonance.
  • The density of the subject affects the dice pool with corresponding modifiers.
  • This includes detecting various forms of energy such as heat, gravity, electromagnetism, and radiation.
  • When scrutinizing energetic phenomena, the mage may face dice penalties for more invisible energies.

name: Influence Light
description:
The mage can guide the direction and/or flow of existing light.

Successes determine the degree to which the light can be altered. For instance, with one success, a light beam can be diverted in a 90-degree direction, while two successes can turn it again by 90 degrees.

name: Influence Sound
description:
The mage can guide the direction and/or flow of existing sound.

She could, for example, focus sound waves from across a vast chamber so she can listen in on a whispered conversation, or ensure that the sound of her own voice does not carry beyond the person to whom she is speaking. She could not amplify the volume, however, or create a noise from thin air.

name: Nightsight
description:
By attuning her perceptions to pick up trace amounts of ambient light, supplementing this with an intuitive feel for vibration, heat and the like, a mage can see in the dark with the same clarity as most nocturnal predators.

Each success lessens by one any penalties for operating under cover of darkness.

Sudden bursts of light can prove disorienting or even painful for the mage and that she will find the light of an ordinary desk lamp to be excessive, while full noonday sunlight is excruciating.

name: Counterspell (Forces)
description:
• The mage creates Pattern interference to weaken or cancel a Forces spell.
  • Mage Sight is required to perceive the attacking spell and counter it.
  • Counterspell can be cast against vulgar spells from mages with higher Initiative.
  • Counterspell can also be used to counter sympathetic spells cast directly at the mage.
  • Successes subtract from the target spell's Potency; if reduced to zero, the spell is canceled.
  • Covert spells require identification before countering, while vulgar spells can be countered immediately.
  • Countering a spell aimed at multiple targets affects all targets.
  • Countering requires at least one dot in an Arcanum used by the attacking spell.

name: Control Sound
description:
The mage can amplify or turn down the volume of sound in an area, such as making the music coming out of a pair of headphones loud enough for dozens of people to hear clearly.

Each success doubles the sound’s volume or diminishes it by half. The effect covers any sound source emanating from within a targeted spot of one-yard radius. For example, if cast upon a podium, anyone standing within that one-yard spot speaks louder than he would when standing outside it.

name: Modulate Speech
description:
With this magic, a passable speaker can sound like a good or even a great orator.

For each success accrued in the casting of this spell, the mage may add a bonus die to all her nonmagical rolls involving speech.

name: Modulate Frequency
description: By casting this spell on audio- and/or video-transmitting devices — or without them, if all of the mages involved are capable of using magic to transmit and receive such signals — a willworker can cause all transmissions to modulate frequency randomly but consistently. In other words: all transmitters, whether devices or spells, within the desired “network” modulate frequency at precisely the same rate, making it extremely difficult for an outsider to spy on the exchange.

name: Control Light
description:
The mage can brighten or weaken an existing light source, such that a 40-watt light bulb can be made to shine as brightly as a floodlight.

Each success doubles the light’s candescence or diminishes it by half.

name: Electronic Eye
description:
This spell allows a mage to read information from magnetic and optical storage media.

By touching a storage medium (or its casing, such as a computer hard drive), the mage can “read” its stored contents as if having access to a machine capable of reading it, such as a computer. The user reads the information at normal human speeds, just as if reading it from a computer screen or listening to it through a speaker. Information in the form of programming (computer code) is recognizable as such, and the reader can disregard it to skim for text and graphics information. The mage cannot “run” software, but can generally determine what it does by reading its code and making an Intelligence + Computer roll.

name: Unseen Shield
description:
Through the use of this spell, the mage deflects incoming attacks with an energy shield, dispersing their force along its invisible contours and causing a punch to land harmlessly.

Kinetic attacks (like fists and bullets) are as surely turned aside as energy-based ones (like a gout of flame or a laser), their momentum stolen or power leeched away.

The mage gains one point of armor per dot he possesses in the Forces Arcana. By spending one Mana, the Duration can be made to last for one day. Most mages cast such a shielding spell at the beginning of the day as part of their morning rituals. Successes are used to combat attempts to dispel the shield.

name: Invisible Object
description:
The mage can render an inanimate object invisible to all forms of sight, including cameras. 

Cast in combination with Influence Sound, the mage can redirect any sounds the object makes (such as the clicking of a camera shutter), making them seem to come from another location.

If the object is moved, it is not invisible (it can be seen) while it is moving.

name: Control Traffic
description:
Through a careful manipulation of electrical current, the mage can cause traffic lights to spontaneously change.

The mage can affect one traffic light (or any similar electronic signaling device) per success. If he simply wishes all targeted traffic lights to change randomly, no further roll is required. Specifying a change, however, requires an Intelligence + Science roll, with a –1 penalty per light beyond the first. 

The mage may continue to change all affected lights for the duration of the spell, as a simple reflexive action to cause a random change or with another Wits + Academics roll (also a reflexive action) to specify the change.

name: Control Heat
description:
The mage can increase or decrease the temperature of an area.

Each success either increases or decreases the temperature in a one-yard radius of the targeted spot by up to 10 degrees Fahrenheit. For example, four successes allow the caster to reduce average room temperature of 72 degrees down to freezing (32 degrees).

name: Kinetic Blow
description:
The mage focuses the force of a physical attack, such as a punch or kick, down to a pinpoint, inflicting damage as though the person on the other end is stabbed with a knife.

Bashing damage is converted to lethal. Attacks that already inflict lethal damage are unaffected. The spell affects one future attack roll per success. The player can choose which of his attack rolls are affected, but he must choose before he rolls the dice for each attack. This effect lasts for one scene (unless additional Duration factors are added during casting), after which time any unused Kinetic Blows are lost.
